head.supplied: 7/6/94 ¶ ¶ In reply to your letter ¶ just received, dear Mr Howitt, let me say, that the ¶ Fallow wood-tree ¶ is Eucalyptus microcorys, concerning which you will find notes in the "Eucalyptography...

div.p:
In reply to your letter
Letter not found. just received, dear Mr Howitt, let me say, that the Fallow wood-tree is Eucalyptus microcorys, concerning which you will find notes in the "Eucalyptography" and "Select plants.
bibliography numbers.
In addition it can be said, that on the wood of this tree most favorably has been reported as to its adaptability for wood bricks to plaster street in Sydney. The veritable Bloodwood-tree is E. corymbosa, treated also int he two works mentioned, but some allied species, such as the far inland-species, E. terminalis, deserve the same name, so the West-Australian E. calophylla, altho' that species is there called Red Gumtree or Blackbutt, beyond what has been mentioned in the "Select plants" and the Eucalyptography" under Euc. piperita, we have here to bear in mind that here widely the same appellation has been bestowed on the variety regnans of E. amygdalina, altho' also the timber of the two is very unlike
Your brief note does not give me a clue to the exact information, desired by you, but if you will write out kindly any definite questions I will answer them to the best of my ability.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: On E. rostrata and E. Leucoxylon many notes occur in the printed timber reports of the successive international exhibitions, but what I said in my own work embraces fairly the main characteristics of these trees. E. odorata is almost confined to the limestone formation at St Vincents and Spencers Gulf. It is not a large tree; our Victorian E. melliodora and E. polyanthema, the so called "Boxtrees" would serve the same purpose and may surpass it in value, but these sorts of trees are not among the quickest growing.
